description: 1747 (as currey, first published recipe for the dish in English), from Tamil கறி (kaṟi), influenced by existing Middle English cury (“cooking”), from Middle French cuyre (“to cook”) (from which also cuisine), from Vulgar Latin cocere, from Latin coquere, present active infinitive of coquō.
Earlier cury found in 1390 cookbook Forme of Cury (Forms of Cooking) by court chefs of Richard II of England.

entries.meaning: One of a family of dishes originating from Indian cuisine, flavoured by a spiced sauce.
A spiced sauce or relish, especially one flavoured with curry powder.

verbs.description: curry (third-person singular simple present curries, present participle currying, simple past and past participle curried)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cook or season with curry powder.

description: From Middle English currayen, from Old French correer (“to prepare”), presumably from Vulgar Latin *conredare, from Latin com- (a form of con- (“with; together”)) + a verb derived from Proto-Germanic *raidaz. More at ready.

verbs.description: curry (third-person singular simple present curries, present participle currying, simple past and past participle curried)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To groom (a horse); to dress or rub down a horse with a curry comb.
(transitive) To dress (leather) after it is tanned by beating, rubbing, scraping and colouring.

examples: […] By setting brother against brother / To claw and curry one another.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To try to win or gain (favour) by flattering.

description: Named after American mathematician Haskell Curry.

verbs.description: curry (third-person singular simple present curries, present participle currying, simple past and past participle curried)

description: Possibly derived from currier, a common 16th- to 18th-century form of courier, as if to ride post, to post. Possibly influenced by scurry.

verbs.description: curry (third-person singular simple present curries, present participle currying, simple past and past participle curried)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To scurry; to ride or run hastily
(transitive, obsolete) To cover (a distance); (of a projectile) to traverse (its range).
examples: I am not hee that can ... by midnight leape my horse, curry seauen miles.
A sermon is soon curryed over.
